dt: {bc}any of a group of small and often winged animals that are arthropods having six jointed legs and a body formed of a head, thorax, and abdomen

dt.t: Flies, bees, and lice are true {it}insects{/it}.

dt: {bc}an animal (as a spider or a centipede) similar to the true insects
This meaning is not scientifically accurate but may be encountered in common everyday use.

pt: The distinct parts into which insects’ bodies are divided—head, thorax, and abdomen—inspired the Greek name used for them by the philosopher Aristotle: {it}entomon{/it}, the {ldquo}notched{rdquo} or {ldquo}segmented{rdquo} animal. ({it}Entomon{/it} is a noun derived from the verb {it}entemnein{/it}, {ldquo}to cut up{rdquo} or {ldquo}to cut into.{rdquo}) The Romans used {it}insectum{/it}, a literal translation of Greek {it}entomon{/it}, as their name for the creatures, and this Latin word has provided us with the ordinary English word for insects.

shortdef: any of a group of small and often winged animals that are arthropods having six jointed legs and a body formed of a head, thorax, and abdomen
an animal (as a spider or a centipede) similar to the true insects This meaning is not scientifically accurate but may be encountered in common everyday use.
